qas.question: Muslims make up how much of the Greek population?
Minority languages have been reduce due to what?
In parts of the country, Romani is spoken by who?

context: The Muslim minority in Thrace, which amounts to approximately <a0_0>0.95%<a0_0/> of the total population, consists of speakers of Turkish, Bulgarian (Pomaks) and Romani. Romani is also spoken by <a2_0>Christian Roma<a2_0/> in other parts of the country. Further minority languages have traditionally been spoken by regional population groups in various parts of the country. Their use has decreased radically in the course of the 20th century through <a1_0>assimilation with the Greek-speaking majority<a1_0/>. Today they are only maintained by the older generations and are on the verge of extinction. This goes for the Arvanites, an Albanian-speaking group mostly located in the rural areas around the capital Athens, and for the <a3_0>Aromanians and Moglenites<a3_0/>, also known as Vlachs, whose language is closely related to Romanian and who used to live scattered across several areas of mountainous central Greece. Members of these groups ethnically identify as Greeks and are today all at least bilingual in Greek.
